abstract.t: This draft is being purposed to provide basic math functions that should be present in all machines, along with very arbitrary calling names that should never interfere with programs already on the machine.

section.title: Introduction and Purpose
section.t: The purposing of this document to the 0x10c standards commitee is to make the proposal for a standard math library, which if the authors of vital utilites such as compilers and assemblers make a standardized library in the future, a math library such as this would be nessacary. Usage of these standardized implmentations of the math functions would also have the advantage of being equally accurate. Two machines would receive the same result for a Sine function.

The author of this draft has worked on a library for such this purpose and would like to recomend it to the commitee as the library of choice for the topic of this document. The author recomends FooMath (https://github.com/MatthewEdgmon/FooMath).

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted and understood as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Features
section.t: FooMath contains functions for working with 16 to 64 bit integers. It includes Sine, Cosine, Tangenent, Exponents, Square Roots, and basic math routines. However usage of the basic math routines for 16-bits acts only as a reference-wrapper function and should not be used.

section.title: Advantages
section.t: The advantages of adopting a standardized arithmetics library now far outweigh the cons. If adopted, then mathematics heavy applications (such as those for finding distance between you and a rock mine for example) have a common ground in their calculating. If the focus of optimizing was spent only on this one library, the amount of time spent on individual apllications optimizing and debugging can be kept to a minimum. Another advantage is that creating a standard library like in C/C++ would have a big task of rewritting all of the math functions. Creating and editing one now would decrease the load work on creating one later, when such a proposal is already underway.

section.title: Disadvantages
section.t: There are no disadvantages. Time spent working on the library by the author serves only as a minor inconvience at best.

section.title: Standardized Usage
section.t: Usage of the library as a source file for use in programs for the DCPU-16 should be made to follow these guidelines. The first guideline is to only use the first callable label of a function. Dissecting the source and looking for mid-function labels to jump to is prohibited and invalidates the standardized usage.

All functions of the library return in A, per commitee standards, and all functions save working registers before executing. If any parts of the library are found to be incompatable with the commitee's ABI, please alert the author.

section.title: Additional Notes
section.t: If FooMath is not a desired choice by the commitee, the author asks it be put on temporarily, and then edited/replaced with a more desired one for whatever reason.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This memo has no applicable security considerations.
